comment: My last lunch in Singapore was yesterday. I thought we were going to take the shuttle to the Heartland Mall (Kovan MRT station) to have lunch then go to this chocolate factory that the folks here keep mentioning but Sheng Teck took us to a new spot to eat, directly across from this chocolate factory. It was like all the other hawker centers I have been to but somewhat cleaner. As always, I find myself pondering what to eat every time because there are so many choices. Luckily, we found a table so I suggested for the 2 guys to grab their food first whilst I hold the table. Little did I know, I did not have to order any food for myself. As I was in line for some rice, roasted pork and char siu, Sheng Teck came up to me to tell me that he ordered enough food for him and I. Awwww, right? That guy literally stole my heart. + the rice was fluffy + portions are quite generous + the roasted pork was super tender + the BBQ pork was succulent + the roasted chicken melted in my mouth He also ordered something else for Jerry and I to try. I had no clue what it was but I tried it and feel like I deserve a medal for trying something I definitely was hesitant about, haha. The food was great. The best was my company. Both guys have a very special place in my heart. Thanks to this trip. I am so grateful. Thank you for treating, Sheng Teck :)

+ :  authentic German breakfast, bakery and more . .. loved the Aunties working the shop, who gave the place such a warm and cozy feel . .. enjoyed thoroughly the "weisswurst mit brezel und sussem senf" or pork sausage with pretzel and sweet mustard: yümm . .. food tasted freshly made: bakery goods in particular (excluding gingerbread girl which was ok, can take or leave) . .. -  :  bathroom, ok (conveniently on-site, his and hers separately; however, i didn't like the wet floor)cAn't wait to visit again - hopefully sOonish!

Werner's Oven is like some of the local cafes in Germany. No frills, simple decor, great food, great service, just plain down to earth goodness. If you're not there for the dine in, one can always purchase the great pastries for takeaways.

The Joo Chiat area is well known for their Vietnamese food, but did you know there's a solid German spot nestled in there as well?My husband and I were looking for a late lunch and since it was one of the few restaurants open mid-day Sunday, we gave it a try. The menu is filled with lots of hearty German fare, from sausages to schnitzel. We split a garlic sausage with sauerkraut and potato salad, and we were impressed! The sausage was juicy, and the sauerkraut complemented the creaminess of the potato salad.I was a little surprised that they didn't offer any soft pretzels as an option for appetizers; if they could do that I think it would make this place even better. However, you can easily walk over to their bakery and grab a few there if you want one with your beer. Prost! :)

The food is very authentic, a lot of homemade food, even sausages, excellent and definitely better than Brot...They also serve Paulaner beer and other German beers and sell wide range of German breads, also homemade.For sure, if you like German sausages you should try!A bit disappointed by the atmosphere but the food quality is more important for me!

Nice quite place for brunch / lunch  Ordered Blue Cheese & Sirloin and specifically requested for choice of fettucini instead of spaghetti.. However the order was served with spaghetti by a apologetic staff saying they had no fettucini. Not too impressed with such poor service as they should ask customer first before preparing the meal. Too hungry to reject the order and wait for them to prepare something else so i took it  The mushrooms are not fresh mushroom but are instead canned button mushrooms. Beef is overcooked and tough. The sauce was salty but its expected cos its cheese.  I will stick to pies and pastries if i patronise them again the next time

Very homely feel. Staff are attentive. Only 2 or 3 but they are constantly looking around to see if anyone needs assistance. Food is great. Beer is good. And if you love soup, try the Pumpkin soup and the green pea soup. And my personal fav is the mashed potato.And oh yes.... They don't have a service charge. But that didn't stop us for leaving a tip.

Their steamboat fish soups never fail to disappoint. There is lots of tiny crackling fried bits of I dunno what that just makes the soup so yummy! For anybody looking for a kick-in-the-butt good tasting fish soup, come here!Har Cheong Kai (Fried prawn paste chicken) here is hard to beat anywhere else. Saturday nights - avoid at all cost. Parking and getting tables is a nightmare. It's so crowded and chaotic. Sundays are a little better if you arrive at 8pm. It's just a really old-school business that serves you good food that's all. Don't expect much service. Oh, and bring cash!

First time there... very tasty soup and they have 3 type of fish for your choice. We chose the white pomfret. It blend so well with the soup, seaweed, yam, salted fish bone ... The price is reasonable too. $31 for a small fish head steamboat, 1 rice and one vege ... be prepared, it is a casual dining. So don't expect to have comprehensive service or good ambience. And it is not a good place to catch up too.
The highlight here is the fishhead steamboat - rich broth, fresh fish, with vegetable, seaweed and yam. One can choose from 3 types of fish - pomfret, coral grouper, and snapper.

The fish head steamboat, with its cabbage and taro, was delicious, but got incredibly salty near the end (duh, since everything evaporated...but there was so much salt (MSG?) in the broth itself that I had a mild headache by the end of evening). We also had the fried chicken wings which were delicious, but the sambal squid kong kang was mushy. Overall, recommended. Just be warned that the service is VERY spotty and you may be waiting awhile to get seated, get your order, get your bill, etc. Cash only.

Love the har cheong kai (prawn paste chicken wings) which came hot and crispy. Not so much into the ngoh hiang which was also highly recommended. The sambal kangkong was spicy and went very well with the rice. The highlight was the fish steamboat which was heated with charcoal. The soup was very sweet and flavorful and filled with fish, yam pieces and veggies. Parking is terrible as there are not many spaces available along the road. It is always crowded, so it may take a while to get a table if you are there during the peak dinner hour. Either go early or later to avoid a long wait. The service is typical of coffeeshop. Quick and efficient, not so much into niceties.

Tadaaa! One of my father's favourite zi char places. Half of my childhood memories were formed going to this restaurant (that's super near the PIE), sitting outdoors on plastic chairs and watching the stray cats meander under the patrons' legs.Everybody goes there to have the fish-head steamboat, aka HUR TAO LOR in local speak. I have to say my father has great taste (not only in finding a wife) - this is DA BEST fish-head steamboat in Singapore. Regardless of your choice of white pomfret or the red grouper, the pre-fried fish is always succulent and fresh, cooked to perfection in the full-flavoured soup. I remember as a kid I liked to select the half-soggy yam pieces from the soup, those were my favourite. The tofu prawn is a recommended side order. Its sauce is a different take with a little bit of spice, but it helps the rice to go down really well.Many people are willing to wait for these piping pots of steamy goodness, that's why we always make it a point to reach before dinner time.Check out eatlikeawhale.blogspot.sg for more pictures and reviews.

I've lived in China for 3 years, one of which was in Chengdu, Sichuan, and this place is the best yet. Black Pepper crab is tops. Although everything was exquisite, including the pot potatoes. Spice with a purpose that is other than to try test my guts. Staff had the best smiles and were present when needed. I do wish the place looked a bit more polished, but that's not necessary for good eats.

address: 112 E Coast Rd #01-06/07 112 Katong Singapore 428802 Singapore
comment: I haven't written about Wine Connection yet? What?!I like this outlet a lot. It's casual, wines by the glass are affordable, and the food is good considering the price point. They also have a nice outdoor patio, though I always prefer to eat indoors.I like their tomato/mozzarella/basil appetizer. Their charcuterie plate is just okay, I didn't find the meats very impressive. In terms of pasta, my favourites are their bolognese and their carbonara.The bottle shop up front always has some good deals going; of course if you live anywhere else the deals are laughable but for Singapore and the sin tax, it's actually not too bad.The staff during my last visit provided great service, always checking in on me and asking how everything is. One of the few shining spots in I12!

address: 112 E Coast Rd #01-06/07 112 Katong Singapore 428802 Singapore
comment: Great food, booze and atmosphereI like this place as you can tell. You can eat well for 50 dollars a head. Well worth a visit

address: 112 E Coast Rd #01-06/07 112 Katong Singapore 428802 Singapore
comment: A bunch of locations around Singapore. This and Robertson Quay are my favorite of the two. A great place to get some wine and cheese and even some pasta or pizza if that's what you like. The best part about it is that you can buy some nice wine from their wine store. I usually stop by if  I know I'm going to entertain that night or if I need a host gift.

address: 112 E Coast Rd #01-06/07 112 Katong Singapore 428802 Singapore
comment: Alcohol is ridiculously expensive in Singapore and so my co-workers and I were very excited when our new office moved very close to Wine Connection. I'm not going to say that the wine is cheap, but the prices are decent. You can get a bottle of wine for as low as $30! I have to say that that's pretty good for any country standards.Although the place says that it's a tapas bar, there is a fairly limited tapas menu, and not that exciting. But I have to say that the fried risotto is pretty fabulous. Their normal food menu, which are all full sized dishes, are all good. The pasta dishes are well cooked and are tasty. The pizza is a bit on the dry side, but good. This is really the place to come if you want to share a bottle of wine with your friends (or maybe just with yourself.) The atmosphere is lively, although it can be very loud. I will, no doubt, be coming here often.

address: 112 E Coast Rd #01-06/07 112 Katong Singapore 428802 Singapore
comment: Perfect if you're stocking up on your own supply, heading to a house party or simply want to chill out by one of Singapore's river with a few select friends (or just by yourself) with a good bottle of wine. What's great about Wine Connection is that besides the fancier, more expensive stuff you can find instore, the first thing you see as you enter or walk by are the bottles on offer... and they're often really good offers. I recently got a bottle of red for $14, and though I'm not enough of a wine expert to describe it in detail, it was good wine, and it was really cheap. So, look out for these offers if you're in an economical state of mind. Head all the way inside and you'll find gourmet bites like truffle oil, spreads, fancy cheese and then some.The only thing about this place I dislike is that they sell Foie Gras, which we all know is about as cruel as shark fin. Besides that, this place is  great for all the gooood wine and excellent prices they have to offer.

address: 112 E Coast Rd #01-06/07 112 Katong Singapore 428802 Singapore
comment: I'm very torn about this place. It has a really nice menu with decent food and wine at reasonable prices, which is a recipe for success in an area like Katong/Joo Chiat. It's flabbergasting how many other similar venues failed in this neighborhood because they didn't get the price/quality balance right, and Wine Connection has to be commended for not assuming that just because there's more expats living here, there's a market for European food at 30+ dollars a dish, and wine at 15+ dollars a glass.They do a lot of things right, from, again, reasonable prices for reasonable food and wine, to a pretty well done interior that gives the right ambiance, to - finally - reasonably late opening hours, something unheard of in this still pathetically early closing neighbourhood! Yes everyone else on east coast road and Joo Chiat, are you listening? If you want to ever become the Holland Village of the east, last order at 9:30 won't cut it.Now, to my biggest, and only issue with Wine Connection, which is a total deal breaker: the noise. This place is popular, and generally quite full, and the interior architect who was responsible for making this place look trendy-hip seems to have gone to great lengths to carefully choose materials that are sure to create the absolute maximum possible reverb, with everyone's voices bouncing off tiled floor, glass/concrete walls, making this place about as loud as the runway at Changi. Having dinner with spouse becomes an eternal 'say again' match, unless you're willing to join in with everyone else and scream your voice hoarse.Wine Connection would be an easy 4 star, but unless the noise is addressed - and it's not so hard, use fabric on the ceiling and it will be much better - it's a 3.

address: 112 E Coast Rd #01-06/07 112 Katong Singapore 428802 Singapore
comment: The auntie inside is friendly, knowledgeable and ready to assist. Most of the stuff is rather affordable, and they also carry more exotic items. I was looking for Velho Barreiro, a Brazilian liqour and popped by to check if WC carried it. Unfortunately no, but the auntie was quick to point out other rums the shop carried. Still, my heart was set on only the Velho Barreiro. After poking about the place, I found a tiny range of Elixia Lemonade at the back of the shop. Artisan lemonade from France! It was really a be-still-my-beating-heart moment. And what's even better was that they carried both the 330ml version as well as the 750ml one, and even the wild strawberry flavoured version. You'd think they'd be pricy but nope, it's all wallet friendly.

comment: Five Spice is the name for the food court that features more than a dozen stalls at the base of Jewel in Changi Airport.  Cheapest, and arguably best, eats available in that part of the airport.

address: 80 Airport Boulevard Viewing Mall Level 3, Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: My experience was terrible.. I couldn't eat there! First when we entered we weren't greeted or given a seat. My aunt was also there and while she was being served one of the staff members instead of listening too the whole order she walked away because another staff called her. She didn't even say excuse me or hold on or anything. I don't think they will see us again!

address: 80 Airport Boulevard Viewing Mall Level 3, Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: I had great experiences having Saboten but never at this outlet before.I was hungry and ready to eat. Already at 6 plus in the evening, the place was packed. thank goodness I didn't have to wait for more than 10 minutes in line. Even though I enjoyed my overall experience, i sure wish i didn't ask for grated radish and ponzu sauce with my tenderloin order. basically the cold grated radish rob me of my experience of eating the cripsy outer crust of the pork katsu and it was soggy and cold almost right from my first bite. lesson of the day:just eat katsu straight up!

address: 80 Airport Boulevard Viewing Mall Level 3, Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: Have been here 4 times. Giving it 4 stars for the following reasons:1. Food quality: They are well known for their tonkatsu sets and they don't disappoint. Their tonkatsu sets are delicious and one of the better ones that you can find in SG. Love their black and white sesame seeds which I always have fun grounding into powder form. Add some yuzu sauce to the grounded sesame and it becomes a perfect dip for the katsu, enhancing its taste tremendously. The tartar sauce that they serve is also really delicious and they will readily give you 2nd helpings if you ask for them.2. Free flow of shredded Cabbage: They are very generous with their shredded cabbage and the wait staff will come round to top up for you again and again. Gotta ask them to stop as one just cannot eat that much cabbage. The sesame and yuzu sauce go very well with the cabbage, making it a really refreshing side dish which helps to balance the taste of the meat dishes.3. Service: Service is friendly, adequate and pretty efficient. Probably a 3.5 stars for service overall.4. People Watching and Admiring Art in motion: The seats are comfortable, especially when you can get the booth seats. If you are seated at the booth seats, you can have a meal while enjoying the action - watching folks checking in at the airline counters at the departure hall below. I always try to get the booth seats and have been lucky to get them in all my past visits. It is also really fun to watch the very impressive art installation Kinetic Rain while dining here.Really into sake (especially hot sake) recently. So, would definitely be returning to Saboten to satisfy my cravings for hot sake and mouth-watering tonkatsu quite soon.

address: 80 Airport Boulevard Viewing Mall Level 3, Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: I was part of a group. 3 of 4 of us got the correct order.  The redeeming part is the food was good. I ordered the pork loin on rice curry set. The panko on the pork and the pork itself were cooked really well. It was nice and crispy on the outside with a perfect color and the pork was nice and juicy and not at all oily. The curry was an average mild curry. I wish there was an option for a hot/spicy curry.

address: 80 Airport Boulevard Viewing Mall Level 3, Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: This is by far one of, if not the best restaurants I've been to in Singapore.  Prices are decent, filling and the meals are fun.  Almost everything I've had on the menu is delicious.  I've been to other locations but will take the 1 hour commute to go to the airport because of the size and ease to get a table.  Love this place!

address: 80 Airport Boulevard Viewing Mall Level 3, Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: I've been here since they opened for business back in 2011. Known the restaurant manager since then too. Always greeted with a smile from her. Service is good.As for the food, I've tried most items on the menu and I stick to my preferred pork loin tonkatsu and curry katsu. I prefer the loin to tenderloin as I like the thin layer of fat at the top of the meat. The breadcrumbs always so crunchy and yet taste remains light. Not oily taste. Nice.The set comes with cabbage free flow, with miso soup and ends with matcha ice cream. Today I top up $1 and gotten myself yuzu ice cream. Yummy. It's always a must come to eat place for me when I'm back in Singapore.

address: 80 Airport Boulevard Viewing Mall Level 3, Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: The perfect tonkatsu lunch is as follows:Crisp, juicy pork loin deep fried to perfection. (That layer of fat makes all the difference.)+Unlimited servings of fresh, thinly sliced cabbage. (Pour on enough dressing and leave it for a while to macerate.) (Yep, macerate.)+Lashings of fragrant sesame dressing for the salad. (Never enough)+Endless servings of fluffy japanese rice. +Sickly sweet brown sauce poured onto freshly ground sesame seeds for dipping sauce (Sesame seeds come in a cool mortar and pestle thing)+Eye watering mustard (just a daub)If I didn't have to wave my arms at all, and had the cabbage magically refill itself, I would give Saboten 5 stars.TIP: Go for the set meal! Comes with miso soup and dessert.

address: 80 Airport Boulevard Viewing Mall Level 3, Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: Overall impressed at the consistency of this Japanese Chain. Very good pork Katsus at a reasonable price.The menu is similar to their other chains, which offers refills of salad and rice. It's a great place to get a fix for anyone craving deep fried Japanese pork. I personally like their Ronsu set which always satisfy me.Be sure to ask for some TartarSauce as I find that their tartar sauce goes especially well with not only their seafood but great with their signature pork.

address: 80 Airport Boulevard Viewing Mall Level 3, Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: Good food at good value. Prompt and courteous service. A good place for a meal before your flight.

address: 80 Airport Boulevard Viewing Mall Level 3, Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: This is a review of a lunch with a colleague at Saboten at Changi International Airport.tinyurl.com/ca2son4I must state that prior to discovering all of the good food in Changi, I reviewed airport eateries on a different scale.  However, Changi blew that scale up.  If the restaurants in Changi were reviewed via my airport scale, they would almost all be 5 stars.Saboten's ambiance is a step above basic  There are touches to accentuate the Japanese influence.  There are splashes of colour.  While nothing lavish, the tables and chairs are also a bit nicer than an average cafe.tinyurl.com/chyafwgThe service was friendly and polite.  However, it was not overly attentive and, at times, it took a little effort to get the attention of a passing server.The food was good to bordering on very good.  We both ordered katsu sets.   They came with lettuce salad & dressing, rice, soup, and ice cream dessert.The Extras - I am not usually a fan of just iceberg lettuce.  But the dressing really took this shreddeed lettuce to another level. It was quite refreshing.  The soup wasn't anything to write home about but it was good.  I enjoyed the green tea ice cream.  tinyurl.com/cccha35tinyurl.com/c8del5utinyurl.com/ck9j5asHitokuchi Hire Tabekurabe (shrimp & tenderloin) - I had the shrimp and tenderloin set.  It came with one piece of shrimp and three medallions of tenderloin.  Each piece of tenderloin was topped with a different sauce; Grated Radish Ponzu Sauce, Ume Sauce, Miso Sauce.  Personally, I thought the sauces were overpowering and the tdelicate taste of the katsu was better without them.   The shrimp and pork were each tasty and tender.  The plate was well presented.tinyurl.com/cmuov88Grated Radish Tenderloin Katsu - This was my colleagues lunch.  He seemed to enjoy it.  But this is primarily for photo reference.tinyurl.com/cphoh9vReceipt (Lunch for 2 - $70.05) - At over $70, this is in no way a bargain lunch.  For the quality and quantity of the food, ambiance, service, etc.., I would rate this as marginally overpriced.  tinyurl.com/buhpbx9Overall - The ambiance is pleasant.  The service, if not amazing, is good enough.  The food is good and the set took care of my appetite.  I do think you can get as good and better for the same money.  If you are already at Changi, I think it is a good option.  If you are not, due to cost, I would suggest seeking another spot to quench your desire for katsu.

address: 80 Airport Boulevard Viewing Mall Level 3, Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: Good food at good value. Prompt and courteous service. A good place for a meal before your flight.

address: 80 Airport Boulevard Viewing Mall Level 3, Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: I have previously written about their Parco branch which I loved and have been recommending to my friends but the one at Changi Airport was just that bit disappointing. I headed down for dinner with the family and ordered more dishes to try.For starters, their ebi is still good at this branch. In fact, so good that my mum had seconds. I like that their prawns was melt in your mouth which adds a nice balance to the crispy batter. The tonkatsu was less than fantastic at this branch which is quite a shame since that was what I really raved about. The bits of oily skin inside which made it rather gross. I thought the one at Millenia Walk was done better with firmer meat to batter ratio and no skin in the cutlet. Tried the mentai cutlet, thought that was okay, nothing to write home about so stick to their original sets. The rice was fluffy and fragrant with fresh shredded cabbages that I love to pair with their sesame sauce. Icecream was the same though in a smaller scoop but that's no biggie. Service is just as polite but I just wished it was easier to get their attention since the service at Milennia Walk's branch was outstanding. I noticed a promotion for $8 breakfasts at this branch for their katsu sandwiches and coffee, so you might want to keep this in mind if you're looking for a breakfast place in the east.

address: 80 Airport Boulevard Viewing Mall Level 3, Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: Quite an OK place. The katsu was not bad at all, even though I've had the same quality katsu for cheaper elsewhere. I visited a friend who was working at Changi during her lunch hour, so it was on an employee discount price. If you're a fan of crowd-watching and airport, this is quite a cool place.

address: 80 Airport Boulevard Viewing Mall Level 3, Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: The portions are smaller than elsewhere and the prices higher, but this remains one of my favorite places to eat on the island, especially while waiting for people to arrive. It is annoying that they usually have an ad at the top of their menu board for airport employees though to eat there for like $9 when everyone else has to pay $25. They must have great profit margins. Welcome to Singapore.

address: Blk 1 Bedok Road Bedok Corner Food Centre Stall no.29 Singapore 469572 Singapore
comment: I don't know why it is so little known but more people should know about some of the gems in Bedok Corner Food Centre. For starters, meet the Hokkien Mee which has been around for as long as, actually, longer than I can remember. It's a personal preference thing but people like their Hokkien Mee different ways. If you like it slightly wet, stocked in rich stock, this Hokkien Mee will work for you. I liked that they pair the yellow noodles with thin vermicelli (most places use thick vermicelli). You get more flavour and less starchy, plus the dish does not dry up as easily and you can enjoy the rich prawn broth with every bite! All the seafood added into the dish was cooked for the right bite so you don't have to worry about rubbery seafood.This is good even for takeaway, the Hokkien Mee stays wet from the rich broth.

Delicious I was so so so bowled over by my airport dinner, since  I was spending a night at an airport hotel. I even forgot to snap pics bc it was so yum!!Save the fact that the satay beef was a bit tougher than what I would like (i.e. had difficulty pulling it off wood skewer with my teeth ), it was still cooked properly and that satay--- can i take a bath in that homemade satay sauce?Nik on Yelp pointed me here.. and lots to say that I would rather try the fare here, with more traditional SG cuisine, over anything offered in shiny, glitzy Jewel for my last dinner in this remarkable and  heady city--state. Difficult to remember that eveRything came to fruition and was constructed only within the past 25 years.My fried chicken (inche kabin ) nasi lemak--forget aboout  it. So so good.. I def see shreds of coconut on the batter for the chicken. UnusualFood is so good in Singapore---

We had a lot of time before our flight. Good thing we had a lot of time, because we stood in line 40 min to be seated! My fried flat rice noodles were really good. My wife and daughter reported their food was "meh".  I drank a unique blend of coffee, tea, and Milo that tasted like an experiment a 8 year old would do in the kitchen.

My one last local dish before I left singapore and I'm definitely happy with the choice. I had their fried rice with satay served with a dollop of sambal. It was good and yummy. Just what I would whip back at home. Service was prompt and good. They wouldn't let you in with your luggage trolley as the wasnt any space to accommodate that in that small restaurant but the lady was nice to let me sit next to my trolley while she parked them outside. I would come back again whenever flying in/out. Thank you for your service

There are some great happy hour prices that can't be beat if you come here on a weekday afternoon. Although the two of us weren't even hungry, we decided to stop and relax here anyway after walking around Jewel. The pork buns are absolutely AMAZING - Tim Ho Wan has really perfected their recipe. Each bun is like a succulent and sweet present for your mouth! The egg tarts are also delicious and very buttery.

Once or if we're lucky, twice every year we get to fly to the Food Paradise that is Singapore. This is one of our "go to" food centres when we're in Singapore.A must dish is the local meal called "Oluak" aka oyster omelette from Green Sky food stall, which is one of the best you'll have in the whole of Singapore for my liking, which not only has generous servings of oysters but also their unique way of cooking it up and the textures are very different that the run of the mill ones, in that it's super crispy and crunchy.From the same stall, you can get a pretty good Char Kway Teow which is usually some sort of seafood and can vary from having an array of prawns, to squid and cockles (a type of shell fish) with flat rice noodles which are all cooked at high heat. The skill of the chef is always evident in how they can infuse the "Wok Hei" aka wok's breath or flavour of the wok into their fare and although it wasn't as noticeable and prominent as some hawkers, it was still beautifully crafted and as much as the Wok Hei is important to the overall flavour of the dish, the little bits of pork lard are a signature too and an absolute must. If you like it a little spicy, ask for chilli when ordering.The usual satay store that we frequent was sold out by the time we arrived but the one we ate at Stall 11 Ayam Penyet (which translates to "flat chicken") didn't disappoint either and the mutton was full of flavour and and these segments of fat that were sweet and so more-ish. If you don't like fat, pass the satay stick on to someone that does. The sauce was nice too but like it's hard to find a bad pizza or bagel in New York, the same can be said for satay but be aware that there are many variations, depending upon the specific influences and regions grounding the chef.For dessert we had our traditional fare of Ais Kacang aka Ice Kacang and Cendol. Ice Kacang is basically shaved ice with flavourings of rose syrup and Gula Melaka (palm sugar) and the kacang part which is usually seaweed grass jelly and red beans and inevitably has attap chee or palm seeds and corn adorning the top. When you go to a beverage shop, they will usually serve hot and cold drinks as well as the refreshing ice kacang but it's almost like a Sizzler smorgasbord in that you can pick and choose what goes into your ice kacang. The cendol looks like little green worms but taste far from it and are sweet rice flour noodles coloured an iridescent green and often paired with coconut.Overall it has to be good if we keep going back there. There's definitely better Kway Teow for my tastes in town but the food stalls at Bedok Corner have yet to disappoint.

Err, is this the Bedok Corner Food Center or Bedok Food Centre??  Anyways after "googling" the proper maps and reconfirming with my cousins, this is the CORRECT/RIGHT Bedok Food Centre that we went.I went here with my cousin and his wife for a late dinner.  Apparently by the time we arrived at this Bedok Food Centre, some of the stalls/food vendors are already closed.  Time was about 20:30hrs ish.  My cousin brought me here coz one there are a few HALAL stalls/food vendors that normally cook Chinese Food or certain cuisine that all 3 of us liked.You can order anywhere but just make sure you inform the Staffs/Food Vendors which table you will be seating, and they will send your food to where you are seated.  Most Food Vendor in this Center, accept CASH.From what I could recall we ordered and shared the following items :*  Satay (Beef & Tripe)*  Sea Snails aka Siput "GONG GONG" aka Dog Conch*  Oyster Omelette*  Cockle Char Kway TeowIn terms of beverages, my cousin opt for Lime Lemon Drink, his wife opt to have the Lychee Drink and I opt to have the Soursop Drink.All in all everything what we had was OK.  At least it satisfy my cravings of Sea Snails aka Siput "GONG GONG" aka Dog Conch coz those are one of many dishes that I grew up eating when my late Grandma cooks it.In terms of the Satay, its doable.  Another favorite of mine was the Satay Babat aka Tripe Satay.  The stall/food vendor that my cousin purchased from, the Satay Babat is tender.  They also know how to make the peanut dipping sauce.  Reminds me of fond memories of the Satay Galore I eat when growing up.I will return to this Bedok Food Corner/Center coz that "FAMOUS" Cheng Tng Stall is also here and there are also other stalls/food vendors that I want to try and drink/eat what they are offering happens to be in this area during Lunch or something.Another note, I just hope they can keep the washroom a little more cleaner coz that evening when I get the chance to use it, wasn't as clean as I was hoping for.

小碗面 Xiao Wan Mian (noodle dish that comes with the "hot pot") - 4 starsThis is the best I've had in Singapore! It came with a ton of ingredients, including lots of vegetables and even two slices of fish! Such a pleasant surprise. Unfortunately the noodles were a little too soft.Wanton Mee - 2 starsMy sis enjoyed the crunchy noodles, but the char siew wasn't good and the dumplings nothing special.Cheng Tng - 4 starsLots of ingredients including candied winter melon and dried persimmon.

When my visitor landed at Changi Airport during dinner time, I picked her up & brought her straight to this very local food center (a hidden treasure) which is not commercialised like Newton Circus or Old Airport. A key reason is that accessibility is only by car or bus (bus#10, 14, 45) Fortunately, my visitor was in light cotton clothing. Like all food center there is no air-conditioning (lots of fans!). Here, I could introduce her to a myriad of local delights, especially the less common ones. And she gets a chance to taste different cultures all at a go. Pit stop # 1 : Ye Lai Xiang Cuttle Fish with water convolvulus (Salad) Best ever Chinese salad. Always wonder why Singapore Airlines doesn't serve this on their flights This is the best executed dishes in SG. Pit stop # 2 : Oleh OlehThe value-for-money towering tahu Telor (fried tofu) at $5 is out of this world! Better than most restaurants.It is a Malay dish that comes with their signature peanut sauce. Pit Stop # 3: Ye Lai Xiang (just next to pit-stop #1)Cheng Teng (Dessert) This is a cooling local Chinese dessert which looks like sweetened consommé. Because the weather is very warm in Singapore, this dessert acts to cool your body system down. It doesn't matter if you are drinking the hot or the cold version. In the bowl, you will find quaint pieces of treasures like sliced dried persimmons, cubed sweet potatoes, barley, gingko nuts, sliced dried melon, white fungus, sago, konnyaku jelly, fresh & dried longans. The BEST Cheng Teng with the MOST ingredients in Singapore is found here. Voila ! We had a yummiest ever VEGETARIAN  dinner with the above pit-stops. For the meat-waters, there is a huge array of Malay & Chinese food which are very good : 1. Ayam Penyet (flattened fried chicken) 2. TFF boneless chicken rice 3. Bedok Corner Hokkien Fried Mee (heavenly Fried noodles !)4. SatayThere are also many stalls selling fresh coconuts too! Enjoy your best ever local food here !!

More ayam penyet stalls than you can shake a stick at. (What does that even mean?) But seriously. There are so many of these dudes here.Thankfully, some of them are good. There's one that even calls themselves the Penyet King. I haven't tried them all, so I'll have to hold my comments.Look out for Kim's hokkien prawn mee. That's delicious. The $15 plate feeds a lot of people, they will like it.There's Ye Lai Xiang chng tng, that's still a treat, and a famous wanton mee too. Plenty to try.

This is my favourite hawker place in the East for me to grab local favourites everytime I crave for them!Here are my picks for you when you are here:Ye Lai Xiang Cuttlefish Kangkong & Cheng Tng, Fried Oyster Omelette from the Nameless Store, Nur Indah Kitchen Ayam Penyet, Homemade Popiah Store, Bedok Corner Fried Hokkien Mee. You can search for individual reviews and pictures of each stall I listed on Yelp. I believe there is more to try here!It gives you a nice mix of popular stalls that everyone has been rating as well as hidden gems. Plus, I like that I get to have a good mix of appetizers, mains and desserts. The food can be a little pricey but it is still much cheaper than any meal in a restaurant so it works for me.

Located right across from Bedok Camp, is Bedok Corner Food Center where many good food stalls are housed. Prepare to be charmed by the modern village setting, with wooden pillars, wooden tables and benches. Muslim stalls and a couple of Chinese food stalls form a circle, lining the food center. Out of the 2 satay stalls, Satay Solo and Jit Sing Satay, my pick has to be Satay Solo. Their meat seems more well-marinated and the sides of ketupat, cucumbers and onions are fresher and crunchier. One of the longest standing stalls there, Bedok Corner Hokkien Prawn Mee never fails to attract a long line. The Fried Prawn Mee is stewed in a rich stock, and holds a relatively strong taste of lard. Ye Lai Xiang, possibly the most famous stall there, occupies 2 stall spaces. One stall sells the ever-popular dessert, Cheng Tng, while the other stall sells Cuttlefish Kang Kong. The Cheng Tng stalls sports a perpetual long queue and it is no wonder, since each bowl is loaded with candied goodies like dried longans, gingko nuts, dried persimmons, sugary melon strips, snow fungus, sweet potato and flour balls. You have to be early in order to get your hands on a bowl, because they usually run out by 9pm.

So many good and halal options available here! Wished I lived nearer so I could eat more. Here are my top 2 recommendations here:1. Tahu Telur at Ole-Ole Javiyan $4Freshly made when you order. So it will take about 5 minutes for the makcik to lovingly prepare this. When you bite into this, it's heaven - crispy egg mixture on the outside and soft, silky, hot tofu on the inside. The brown sauce is not as spicy as I'd like it to be, but, good enough for that shiok factor. The crushed peanuts adds a good texture to this very satisfying dish. 2. Chicken rice at Tong Fong Fatt*I'm a Muslim so I have not eaten much authentic non-halal hainanese chicken rice*I've always preferred the hainanese chicken rice over the Malay chicken rice as the latter tends to be greasy with almost everything fried. This plate of chicken rice from TFF is amazing - rice is fragrant and fluffy, the steamed chicken is soft and succulent (you have a choice of roasted or steamed), the soup is alright and the garlic chilli adds a nice balance to the whole dish.

Bedok Corner Food Centre (or to many known as the Bedok Camp market)  is a hidden gem of the East.  There are many yummy food you can find here and you will not go home disappointed unless the items are sold out. Home to many of popular local eats, it can get very crowded here in the evening. Here are some of the popular findings worth mentioning at this place are as follows (in no order of preferences):  Cheng Tng, Cuttlefish Kang Kong, Fried Hokkien Mee, Kambing Soup, Ayam Penyat, Mee Kuah Upeh and Satay.Whenever I am in the eastern part of singapore, I will often request to have my meals here. Everyone goes home happy dining here.

address: 75 Airport Boulevard Terminal 3, Level 2 Departure Lounge Singapore 918141 Singapore
comment: The Kitchen is my preferred choice for a meal while I am in T3 of Changi. The food comes out quick and the taste is on point. Not sure why the reviews here are so negative. Food: 4 starsService: 4 starsValue: 3 stars Recommendations: WP burgerI have been here twice and both times I have ordered the WP burger. The burger here is very good and I recommend ordering it.  This visit I replaced the fries with a side salad. The salad is dressed and salted properly. I would definitely order this again if I don't want to feel to full heading on to the plane.

address: 75 Airport Boulevard Terminal 3, Level 2 Departure Lounge Singapore 918141 Singapore
comment: A welcome site - avocado on the menu! After a few weeks' travelling, I arrived at Changi airport and felt hungry - what to eat that's not junk food and won't take long? Wolfgang Park delivers - avocado on toast with poached egg, tomato, green salad, onion and feta. I immediately sat down and ordered (leaving out the toast). Service is attentive and speedy - being mindful of every diner's eye on the departure board. My food came quickly and it was great -  very generous with the avocado and a nice, fresh, colourful, healthy dish - it was all fabulous, thank you.

address: 75 Airport Boulevard Terminal 3, Level 2 Departure Lounge Singapore 918141 Singapore
comment: Service was ok, but the steak was most likely from a cow that was 100 years old because it was like eating seasoned shoe leather. I think my mother in law lost a tooth trying to eat hers. Avoid the steak at all costs. I'm sure Wolfgang doesn't know about it yet.

address: 75 Airport Boulevard Terminal 3, Level 2 Departure Lounge Singapore 918141 Singapore
comment: my First time come here bcoz of  my friend invite me. We tried the salad , buger , pizza , cake , really nice , the staffs here are nice and asking the feedback of the food , that is the best thing will keep the restaurant doing the best , recommend !

rest_name: Indonesian Cuisine Stall - Bagus - Changi City Point
address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #B1-32/33/34 Changi City Point Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: I ordered grilled ayam with satay sauce. The sauce was cruncy and not oversweet. The chicken was grilled to perfection with a sweet salty soya sauce mixture.  The rice was a perfect accompaniment with the sambal at the side. It's just like having satay with ketupat juz enlarged version. The winner is the tender juicy chicken.

rest_name: Indonesian Cuisine Stall - Bagus - Changi City Point
address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #B1-32/33/34 Changi City Point Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: This is a review of a solo lunch at the Indonesian Cuisine Stall at the Bagus food centre in the basement level of Changi City Point.i was wandering around taking photos of some of the food purveyors in Changi City Point.  I was a tad earlier than normal for lunch.  So, I decided to try out a stall in Bagus, the basement food court located there.  During normal lunch hour, it is usually just too busy of an option.I selected the Indonesian Cuisine stall.  I am a big fan of Ayam Bakar.  Plus, the food on their counter looked very fresh and delicious.tinyurl.com/afloc3oThe attendant was exceedingly friendly.  I placed my order.i roamed around and went to the drinks stall and purchased a lime juice.  I found a spot in the still near empty food court and placed my lime juice there.By the time I made it back to the stall, my food was ready.  it looked fantastic.  Ayam Bakar - For a stall, the presentation was very well done.  The chicken was tender.  The spices were great.  The skin had an almost smoky flavor.  The rice was well prepared.  There was what I think was fried tofu.  But it might have been something else.  This was not my cup of tea.  The fresh cucumber slices were refreshing.  My only real complaint was the portion of chicken was a bit small.  it wasn't long before I was hungry again.  But I thought the $5.50 was a fair price for the meal.tinyurl.com/b88xssqOverall - Friendly service and tasty food in a clean food centre made for a very good lunch.

address: 6 Changi Business Park Ave 1 #01-31, North Office Tower, UE Biz Hub East Branch Singapore 486017 Singapore
comment: This is a review of a solo lunch at the recently opened Shin-Sapporo Ramen - UE Biz Hub East - Changi Business Park.After aborting lunch at another nearby restaurant, I wandered around checking out some of the other recently opened offerings.  I decided on Shin-Sapporo Ramen.tinyurl.com/b9cf62sThe staff is very friendly.  The service is brisk and polite.  I am not a fan of the constant yelling hello(?) thing but I get that it is a part of the experience.The ambiance is clean, new, basic, and functional.tinyurl.com/a58dr8cI was quickly greeted and seated.  Soon after, my order was taken.  My beverages were brought in a jiffy.  Not long after, I had my tasty bowl of Katsu Don.Katsu Don/Pork Cutlet - Out of their extensive menu, I selected the Katsu Don with pork cutlet.  They do have a set lunch option.  But, I decided against it.  The food was freshly prepared and neatly presented.  It was quite good.  There were two minor negatives.  The dish was slightly bland.  I remedied this with my own additions.  The pork cutlet was slightly tough.  However, this was  not enough to detract from the overall meal.  The portion was generous.tinyurl.com/b43nm7dReceipt ($18.00)tinyurl.com/bxywfm2Ok, at 18 bucks for one person, this was not an inexpensive lunch.  I did mention there are more economical set lunches and I decided against these.   Even with these, if you are on a tight lunch budget, Shin--Sapporo may not be the lunch spot for you.Overall, friendly and efficient service combine with a clean ambiance and well-prepared food to provide an enjoyable lunch experience.  The only real negative is that it may not be right for everyone's lunch budget.

address: 6 Changi Business Park Ave 1 #01-31, North Office Tower, UE Biz Hub East Branch Singapore 486017 Singapore
comment: My first night in Singapore and I had to try the ramen at Shin-Sapporo. I wasn't disappointed, not at all. Flavour from the very first mouthful to the last and a great portion size meant I was well fed but most of all was in ramen heaven.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #B1-26/27 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: This is for the Palza Singapura location. Sometimes one can over automate simple processes. We ordered our food through the app, but forgot to order water. When I asked the server for water,  she was totally confused.  See...I did not order water, so the robot did not know to bring it to us. The server was not the least bit heloful...BTW, they charge .50 for water. Guess they have to pay for the robot somehow. Anyway, this is the second time that I have seen the server robot...once in the US, and here. In the US, a person actually takes the food from the robot and serves you...here...the robot comes to the table and you fetch your food. Not sure if I am a fan.Our order was simple: pho, chicken skewers, and chicken rolls. After 35 minutes,  our pho finally  came out...by human, no robot...5 minutes later, the accoutrement came out. 5 minutes later, the rolls. 5 minutes later, she comes back to confirm that we ordered chicken skewers. This is the same person who would not give us water.  Not a fan. Never coming back Too impersonal and poor service...bad combination .

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #B1-26/27 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Accidentally choose this restaurant for lunch along with Ley Ley while checking out the factory outlets. Arguably some of the best Vietnamese food in Singapore. The spring role platter was wonderful as was their signature grilled chicken. Highly recommend!

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #B1-26/27 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Authentic enough Vietnamese menu although the waitresses were Chinese. The grilled chicken and pork cutlets were flavourful and the children loved them. The summer rolls and spring rolls were normal fare. The snails were not prepared the way I'd expected but they were generous with the garlic chips which added to the fragrance of the dish. Loved that they served Vietnamese desserts! Hard to find such authentic dessert in Singapore.

Saw the good reviews and found our way here. Had to park at F3 car park and walk over. Myra's is housed in this really interesting corner of a building I know not of but when you're at the right side of the restaurant, you'll get the beautiful view of the sea. We order their promotion of 5 beers and Salsa with Chips for $50 which was a great deal. And we also had the Mexican Non-Vege Platter which was a great choice. Good for the two of us to have a adequate sample of everything we wanted to try in the menu. And every item in the platter actually tasted very good. Will definitely order that again!The night we went, it was a very balmy night and we even felt up for a after-dinner stroll which was romantic just by the beach.

We went to the Fort Canning location, but I don't see that listed here. Myra's at Fort Canning is set in a plush location against the National Museum, inside Fort Canning Art Center. Bold, yet discreet since it is tucked away in the basement. Yet, it is at a level where there is a nice balcony that faces onto the grounds. The flavours were distinct and no two items tasted alike, very good food overall. It wasn't crowded, yet the service could have been way more spiffy.

Its probably the best place for a margarita or their spicy mexican beer (really spicy) when the weather is pleasant.. Otherwise, the humidity takes over the novelty factor.Food is good because you get the best of mexican and indian. Both are tastefully done.Would have given one more star but when i was there, it was a really humid afternoon.
Excellent food, a great mix of Indian and Mexican. Superb ambiance and warm service.. One of my favourite restaurant in Singapore.

This restaurant in East coast park provides sea views along with Mexican and Indian food. The view is stunning as is the food. The abundant flies were quite popular and whenever they couldn't get any food, they got to the table and cutlery. Food was not overly underpriced compared to the deflated quality. Definitely will not go back as we were probably underdressed for the lackluster ambiance.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #B1-38 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Take away only spot in the busy Changi business Park. They serve burritos, bowls and kebabs. Good mixture of Mexican and Turkish food. I got the chicken burrito bowl which was filling and healthy. Cash only and it gets busy at lunch time so be prepared for a little wait.

address: 1 Changi Business Park Crescent #02-19/19A Plaza 8 Singapore 486025 Singapore
comment: This is a review covering multiple lunches at Himawari Japanese Restaurant which is located on the second level of Plaza 8.tinyurl.com/b4b3jm7This is the nicest of the dining options in Plaza 8.  While not elegant, at least on one side, the ambiance is a touch more sophisticated than just basic tables.  However, on the other side, the environment does fall back to a simple more functional presentation.  But there are still more small touches to provide some basic character to the room.Dining/Sushi Bar Side - This is the nicer seating area.  However, it is important to note that not all of their menu is served on this side.tinyurl.com/aomyq3nTables and Chairs Side - This is the more basic seating area with simple tables and chairs.  I would note that while it is not apparent in the photo, this side of the restaurant is usually quite dark.  For lunch, I prefer an ambiance with plenty of lighting.tinyurl.com/b27sj55The service has always been very good.  The servers have been attentive and helpful. The food has generally came out quickly and the staff check to see if the meal is going well.The food ranged from good to very good.Fish w rice bowl - I enjoyed this dish.  I do think the flavor of the fish is a touch over powering.  I would probably enjoy it more if a fish with a more delicate flavor was used and other flavors were also allowed to shine through.tinyurl.com/a2338snChicken Katsu Don - This was very good.  The chicken was tender and, when combined with the egg, it was delicious.  I really liked the texture of the  rice also and the addition of the scallion and seaweed provided a nice contrast in texture and flavours.tinyurl.com/a48nn45Overall, if you need to slightly impress someone and you need to have lunch in Plaza 8, this is probably your best bet.  The bar side is quite nice.  The staff is on point.  The food is relatively good.  They have an extensive menu.  However, as I previously mentioned, the entire menu is not available on the sushi bar side of the restaurant.

address: 1 Changi Business Park Crescent #02-19/19A Plaza 8 Singapore 486025 Singapore
comment: Just basic... Japanese quality? nope... Restaurant cannot survive a month in Japan...

This was the first place I ate at during my trip to Singapore bc it was one of the earliest opening stalls at the airport which was nice bc we arrived at 5 am  by 7:30 when they opened there was already a line. It seemed like a lot of people were there for teh or coffee and the guy making it was going hard!! He was pouring huge pots of drinks while also taking peoples orders which was very mesmerizing and impressive. It wasn't all for show either because the teh was delicious! Actually, everything was good. We got the classics: curry noodles, nasi lemak and kaya toast. The two entrees also came with a slice of cake each so I got the Kaya and kopi flavors. The kaya one was my favorite!! Super thick buttercream and not too sweet. I came back again when flying out of the airport and tried their mee reebus which was also very tasty - it's like curry gravy. I let my dad have a taste and he ended up eating most of the noodles -__- So yes highly recommend for good flavor and fast early service! The prices aren't bad either

Breakfast is a celebrated tradition in Singapore.  Coffee and toast culture is a popular lifestyle. With tourists always on the go, Toast Box offers this sugar laced "National breakfast" set in a deliciously convenient way that is also easy on the wallet.  The chain features a small menu of traditional fares in a simplistic contemporary setting.  Sweet and savory dishes as well as their signature Nangyong Coffee Kopi are on offer. We opted for their Kaya Toast and Kopi set as well as a bowl of their Laksa. The Kopi was tasty and the Kaya Toast although toasted, it still maintained it softness was just ok. The butter was overwhelmingly salty. Not something I'd recommend. However, the Laksa was surprisingly delicious! Though not as widely popular at this chain, it's definitely giving other venues a run for its money IMO. The perfectly cooked noodles bathing in a rich and aromatic coconut sauce with a generous amount of toppings were delightful to the very last bite! If you can't make it to one of the more celebrated joints, Toast Box is a great alternative for this Singaporean signature dish!

address: 60 Airport Blvd Level 3, Departure Lounge Singapore 819643 Singapore
comment: If you're flying out of Terminal 2 (or have time to make it over to T2), the TGM restaurant is an absolute must benefit for Priority Pass holders. You get a full bento out of a list of choices and especially if you're flying an LCC like. Scoot or Air Asia, the bento, with its diversity of delicious dishes, will sustain you for your upcoming flight and avoid you having to buy a crummy meal onboard.The tables are equipped with USB and AC power so the restaurant is essentially a pretty good lounge as well, with food being brought out to you and not people just randomly walking around you trying to get to a bar or buffet. Definitely check it out. It puts any other Priority Pass lounge to the background when it comes to food.

address: 60 Airport Blvd Level 3, Departure Lounge Singapore 819643 Singapore
comment: Great for free with the priority pass.  Comes with Salmon, escolar and albacore tuna as well as three pieces of karaage with rice and miso.  You also get a choice of soda or tea.  Everything was done well.  Will definitely be back

address: 60 Airport Blvd Level 3, Departure Lounge Singapore 819643 Singapore
comment: Nothing is worse than the feeling of utter regret as you're flying 40,000 feet above the ground after eating a greasy, fast-food meal. That's why when I'm traveling, I prefer to eat food that is as simple and as "clean" as possible. The Green Market, located on the 2nd floor of Terminal 2, fit the bill pretty well.4/5 Ambience: The restaurant has a modern Japanese design that'll have Instagram gals/guys going gaga. Eating there is also much more peaceful compared to the hubbub of the food court just down the hall.3.5/5 Food: My first time stopping by, I ordered the chicken donburi. It didn't taste anything remotely Japanese. It was more like a bland version of a Hong Kong chicken clay pot dish.My second time, I ordered the sashimi bento box and I liked that so much better. It came with 6 slices of sashimi, rice, miso soup, fruit, okra, and salad. Tbh, not the best sashimi I've had, but it was a simple and filling meal, so I left happy.4/5 Service: Multi-lingual servers who are attentive but not intrusive.Overall, definitely not the best Asian food I've ever had, but for airport food, it's not bad at all.

address: 60 Airport Blvd Level 3, Departure Lounge Singapore 819643 Singapore
comment: GOOD AIRPORT FOODThis is a nice little sit-down restaurant. I had the Salmon Bento Box and, I must say, it's one of the best I've ever had.Service - 4 starsFood - 4 starsLocation - 4 starsAmbiance/Decor - 4 starsDon't leave a tip. They automatically add in 10%.

address: 60 Airport Blvd Level 3, Departure Lounge Singapore 819643 Singapore
comment: got this through my lounge membership and was blown away by the set meal, grilled fish. if you have the option just go here instead of another lounge. staff is good and food delivered.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: For a place called Table Manners, it is (ironically) casual and irreverent with a nice chill-out vibe. It was quite full even for a weekday night so we were glad we had a reservation.For starters, I had the pumpkin soup and I found it to be on the lighter side in terms of depth and flavour. It worked well with me but may not for others who prefer thicker soups. I also had the Truffle Capellini with organic egg. It was delicious, with the truffle not overwhelming and just right. The egg was a good mix with the capellini. As for my partner, she had the mussels with spicy cream. The mussels were juicy and succulent, though it will be even better if there were more!We both had space for dessert and shared a sea salt chocolate caramel tart. The tart was a nice touch to a good meal overall and would definitely be agreeable for those with a sweet tooth.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Wasn't too bad for a chill spot in the eastQuiet but easily accessible in changi city point Truffle fries was good Salmon was good but thought the portion was way too small. Tomato and mozzarella salad was subpar

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Table manners is a great place at City point where there are great choices for eating.  Western food mostly.  The best thing on their menu is the truffle chicken - salty and a little sweet.  I always order the appetizer, but I think they have a main entre.  A regular stop fore when visiting signapore, but recently the food has been coming out fast but a little undercooked /rare.This place is a great place with friends or work associates.  Sit inside or out.  Music tends to spill over from other places.  Great place to people watch with a cold beer.  Happy hour prices are good too.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Service was pretty efficient for a Saturday night. We were thinking between the specials that were on and ultimately decided to go for the Aglio Olio and the braised beef shank if i remembered correctly. Food was fast and tasted not too bad . :) We were done within an hour. Will probably sometime again.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: They ran out of pancakes for brunch?! Unbelievable.How can you possibly run out  of pancakes unless you're indirectly telling me you're using frozen pancakes?! *Horrors!Fresh pancakes should be made fresh and I'm sure the ingredients used to make the batter are basic ingredients that all kitchens should never run out of!"nuff said.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Wow!!! First off, the mushroom soup is awesome!! Very flavourful and totally not out from a can! I can drink a gallon of this!!!Salmon was an ok size and nicely grilled. Can taste the crispy-ness to it! Nice!Mushroom Ragout is also well cooked. Savory and mushroom had that right bite to it!Mash is tasty but a little fluffy I guess. I supposed I like my mash heavy with butter and everything unhealthy. This mash is light but still tasty!Hubby's steak is also ok in size and in taste. Not bad but not OMG. May order something else the next time. Scrambled Eggs are ok, a little too runny and bland according to hubby. He claims he makes better ones. Heh...Lunch was rounded up with a Coffee Hazelnut Cake. It's very light! Can taste the coffee and hazelnut. Not bad at all. I'm not into coffee hazelnut dessert but it's decent. We'll definitely be back!

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Its a nice cosy place.I thought there were plenty of choices in the menu.Weekends there's a weekend brunch menu till 3pm.I tried the set a option.Chose the scrambled eggs, truffle fries and sauteed spinach.The scrambled eggs were OK and truffle fries were more like fries.The sauteed spinach tasted sourish but I think it went really well with the scrambled eggs as the me went on.My friends tried the eggs Benedict and steak.If you're into eggs...I suggest give eggs and berries a go instead of table manners.The steak was good and the chicken was alright.All in all it was a nice place. Food nothing to rave about.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: (Note - the review relates to the quality of coffee served only).Table Manners is the latest venture from the team behind Bar Stories at Haji Lane. Bar Stories deserves a post of it's own - it's one of the most unique and memorable bars that I've visited, in any of the cities that I've lived in. It's sister outlet, Table Manners, has a unique selling point - the creativity of Bar Stories combined with the coffee crafting expertise of Papa Palheta. This would be a potent combination in any part of Singapore, but particularly so in an area that until recently had been starved of quality coffee. As always, I ordered an espresso and a cappuccino, two drinks that tell me a lot about the quality of coffee in any given cafe, bar or restaurant. The espresso shot was thick, with definite hints of citrus. This gave rise to a full bodied aftertaste that lingered long after the last drops of espresso had been gulped down. It seemed thicker and more potent than a regular shot - more akin to a ristretto - this was a shot that was extracted for the correct eighteen to thirty second extraction time. This may seem like a minor point, but it's an important one - it's harder to make bad coffee with a good espresso foundation.The shot had a medium dark crema, which lined the side of the cup. It's interesting to note that a lot of the perceived bitterness in an espresso shot comes from the crema itself. If you carefully scoop the crema from a fresh espresso shot, it should taste extremely tart. Crema which clings to the side of a cup will not impart as much of this sharp flavour to a shot. This was a good shot by any standard, but it would also be a good shot for anyone who has not tried espresso shots before, or for anyone who has been turned off espresso by bad shots in franchise chain cafes.    The cappuccino has a thin layer of foam, closer to that seen on a latte. As a result, the smooth and silky mouthfeel was reduced, making this a lighter cappuccino (I prefer mine stronger), but the quality of the drink was not overly diminished. One issue is that teacups are being used rather than coffee cups - the difference being that tea cups have very thin walls, and as a result, heats dissipates much more quickly (I'm a science geek. I can't help but notice these things). Combined with the overhead fans above, coffees can lose heat quite quickly, and this has a significant effect on the quality of coffee served. It's worth pointing out that coffees in Table Manners are no more expensive than those in franchise chains. Why waste good money on bad coffee when Table Manners has Papa Palheta's beans? However, prices on the take away menu need to be updated. A latte is listed as costing $5, but actually costs $5.90 - this should be an easy thing to fix, but it's still there. Latte art is always a welcome sight, as it tells me that the baristas were trained to a high standard, and trained to care about quality coffee. This is consistent with my comments on the espresso shot being prepared correctly. The light dusting of cocoa powder ensured that little sweetness was imparted, and that the cocoa flavour accentuated rather than dominated the drink.The food menu is worth a mention also - there is a good selection of starters, main courses and deserts, and an interesting menu that allows items to be paired according to the customers preferences. The prices are fair - they are certainly not overpriced - another point in their favour.In a nutshell, the bright young staff at Table Manners are serving up quality coffee, made from quality beans in a quirky and interesting bar and restaurant. Bar Stories younger sibling is already off to a good start....but change the cups and update the prices on the take away menu!

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: This is a review of lunch at Table Manners.  This was a group lunch.  However, I am going to narrow  my review to my personal experience.First, the tee shirts with the painted on ties have got to go.  It may seem like kitsch cool.  But it is just plain tacky.The ambiance is modern with clean lines.  It has a bit of a spartan feel.We were quickly seated.  Everything flowed in a timely manner; drinks order, food order, drinks out, food out, etc..The staff was friendly. I ordered the set lunch with fried chicken, mashed potatoes, salad, and strawberry shortcake.When my order arrived, they had given me mushrooms instead of potatoes.  I brought it to the servers attention.  He took my plate away and quickly returned.  They had simply added maybe two spoons worth of mashed potatoes to my plate.  Come on, potatoes are one of the least expensive foods in the world and, after making a mistake on my order, they skimp on them.The fried chicken was pretty good.  It was certainly not the traditional fried chicken that I kind of expected.  It was prepared more like chicken fried steak. It was a large boneless piece of chicken pounded out, breaded and fried.   It was nothing to write home about but I liked it.tinyurl.com/93wn6a2The strawberry shortcake was a fresh, light, and refreshing dessert.tinyurl.com/96shz52Overall, this is a basic place.  It is much like the restaurants next to it (Moa and Lavaedge).  It is not an inexpensive lunch.  But, it doesn't empty your wallet either.  Out of convenience (close to work), I might go back.  However, it is definitely not a place to venture out of your way to visit.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Table Manners - abbreviates TM, is one of the interesting bistro in the newly opened - Changi City Point, a mall sits directly opposite the Singapore Expo MRT station which can be conveniently reached. I almost lost my way in the mall while trying to locate TM. Without any visible signage and especially difficult when the mall has quite a number of small exits around. I don't seem to be able to spot the restaurant until I reached the open space - a small garden-like area. There, I saw a black outdoor gazebo dining area with an open counter featuring a prominent "pigeon-hole" backdrop. I knew I have found it and walk right up. I was greeted by a zealous wait staff at the door, who explained the ordering instructions patiently and thereafter showed me to the indoor seats.Entering the dining hall, it is the democratic design that I saw. I could imagine how the people behind TM conceptualized the area, decking out in modernistic Scandinavia-inspired furniture characterized by simplicity and practicality. The "piecemeal" communal table stood out from the space, without looking cluttered. The area was highlighted by the wall shelving with potted plants, retail pieces stuffed in each pigeon holes. Fitted mostly in pressed wood, the room was made less formal with a sense of nature integration. The first thing that comes to mind is Ikea, this group of Swedish makes really sensible tools with a small price tag.Lunch is served in a mix-and-match manner, where it comes with 4 main categories; "fibers" - Staples & Vegetables, "protein" - Seafood & Meat. You can choose to have the lightest meal with 3 fibers for $9.50 or the hearty combination of 2 fiber and 2 protein for $19.00. of course, if these ain't going to fill you, get some add-ons and pay additional $3.50 - $7.50. I customized my plate with a mid-sized combo plus 1 add-on & a dessert to end the meal.The lightly salted Truffle fries are so addictive that I can't stop but emptied the bowl within a short 10 minutes. Each string was deep fried to crisp and I liked the fact that they are cut fatter than any shoe-strings yet sliced slimmer than the regular straight fries. Smell of comfort, less gasoline taste - a great snack packed in umami-rich aromas. Go for potato wedges if truffle fries seem less idolizing.The Chopped Pumpkin Salad came with a decent portion of fresh greens. Never mind if the diced pumpkin looks miserable, a generous toss of that tangy salad dressing add scores to the boring greens. I was looking for a sweet flavour in the pumpkin but the morsels were too tiny to taste.The Cajun seasoning lends a sweet and spicy scent to the sizable chicken thigh. One incision and you witnessed how moist and tender the meat was roasted, with the bursting juices oozing out onto the plate. It was quite close to what I have eaten at Amuse, a delicious piece of bird meat. Other "protein" like beef stroganoff, pork cutlet, pesto fish fillet and burger steak, are available as well. There's nothing you won't choose.That additional fiber I had - Spaghetti Pomodoro akin tomato sauce was equally tasty. The pasta had a good boil, yielding a springy bit but it will be perfect if it was cooked Al dente. Every strand was coated in the mildly acidic tomato sauce, fair amount of concentrate yet not overly seasoned. Sometimes when I am really unlucky, I get some bad tasting pasta that either comes with a chunk of soggy noodles or a pool of unpalatable watery sauce. Here, no slipshod piece of work seen.yelp.com.sg/biz_photos/t…What is a complete meal without a sweet ending? You've guess it! A chocolate-caramel war. Undoubtedly, the sweet course didn't come cheap, ranging from $6.50 - $7.50. But I am willing to foot the price if it tastes divine. I am split between a Strawberry Shortcake and the chocolate tart. In the end, the latter succeeded in talking me over. Fabulous piece of tart. The shortcrust crumbles neatly on my plate each time I forked right through. The highlight was that chilled chocolate fillings - soft and chewy. The cocoa flavour was explosive, so intense. Each mouthful was gooey when the chocolate fused with that sticky caramel substance in the middle. Flavour becomes good when it has a lot of layering and this Sea Salt Chocolate Caramel Tart depicts that - speechless.Coffee addict will not leave TM without a good Papa Palheta dose. The potion was rich, aromatic, not acrid - truly a stimulant. Not a fan on coffee? How about a cup of tea from Tea Forte? And if you are in the mood for some cocktails, they have the so-called popular drinks from Bar Stories presented in 5 groupings, that is, sweet, spicy, sour, bitter, and intriguingly to chill you.Though lesser known by diners, you could pick up anything from this retail-cum-cafe that fits a housewarmin

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: A failed concept: Food literally tastes like chap chye peng with western ingredients. The coffee was bland. The dessert, a blue berry cake, was mushy too.We ordered brunch: chicken thigh, sunny side up, sautéed spinach and mushroom ragout. Almost every dish was below expectations considering the prices. The only exception was the mushroom soup that came with the set. It was drizzled with truffle oil and did bring out the taste of the mushrooms.The only saving grace of this restaurant is its ambience. It is pretty cosy and the outdoor seating area is not too warm.  Table Manners will probably be better off as a pub than a cafe.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: In theory I love the concept, but in reality I only just like it.Pick and mix a combination of veggies, carbs and proteins depending on your hunger level and budget. There's some suggested combinations if you want to know what goes together, otherwise you can take a punt and hope they all go together. I got the salmon with a side of broccoli and mixed vegetables. I need greenery and this sounded like a healthy option. Sadly the vegetables came slathered in butter/oil and the salmon had a creamy dressing on top. It tasted fine but my tastebuds certainly weren't delighted. Next time I'll choose my combo more carefully.What I really loved about Table Manners was the fitout. I love the interior of this place - kind of like a Scandinavian library feel (not that I have any idea what the libraries look like in Scandinavia). There's free wifi and a chilled vibe, so it's also the perfect place to sit for a while if you need to have a meeting or do some work.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Let's start with this - I really like this place. It's not trying to do too much, and with what they do do, they do it well.Our gang of six had a couple of different options, and all of us polished out plates - the truffle capellini had great flavour, and that yolk seemd to bind the flavours together, while my Louisiana fried chicken was not so much Southern, yet a very well battered and fried chop, so I didn't really have a lot to complain about. With very reasonable prices and a daily three-hour happy hour deal, you'll find a reason to come back.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Chances upon this new establishment when we dropped by Changi City Point. The setting is very casual, unique in fact. There is a Z shape long table (made of little ones) that pack diners in the middle of the space. If you want a little more intimacy, then you can opt to sit at the row of tables at a corner of the room. Outdoor seating is in a bird cage like gazebo just outside the restaurant.Onto the food. Enjoyable and hearty western cuisine. I was eyeing the Angus beef steak with truffle fries but it was sold out. Had the pork cutlet with aioli which was quite good. Very juicy and tasty. The baked salmon also won the boy's vote with its flavorful sauce. Drinks are from Bar stories, a sister company of Table Manners! There's happy hour from 5-8pm every day. Awesome!! Like their page on FB and you get 20% off the bill. :)) not sure when the offer ends though.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Picked this place as it was busy as that is usually a good fine. Food was not good quality and just blah. Ordered a glass of wine and it had gone bad and was oxidized. Told the waitress and she said she would tell someone, but then no one came.  My son's food had a bug in it

comment: Made a reservation for 4,asked for indoor seating. The table layout is all joined. Felt like I was eating in a canteen. Strangers "cosying" up next to me. (To be fair, the waiters did ask/inform us that other customers will be seated next to us)Was actually looking forward to big portions based on the earlier reviews, heehee, but it's only average  (IMO). Started 2 sides (crusted oysters and baby squid calamari) while waiting for our 3 mains (platter combo, seafood spaghetti, seafood & chicken jambalaya). The pork ribs are tender and slides off the bones. Hubby loved the Cajun sauce. The other mains are only so-so. The guys are still not full and ordered the spicy wings and other portion of the baby squid calamari. The spicy wings are using the Cajun sauce again so hubby is thrilled again. (Although one of my guests think it's too spicy). The baby squid calamari is a favorite that we had to order a second portion. Apparently this dish is a sneak preview and will be introduced next year. Overall, the taste is decent. Although, I can't agree with the other reviews that the price is value for money.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-68/69 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Good food, average pricing. Ordered Aglio olio, truffles fries and iced lemon tea. Seating wise was like a zig zag of long tables good for big gatherings not so much for private seating. Pasta was nice with a big sausage. Fries tasted different from normal fries but wasn't sure it tasted "trufflety" iced tea was refreshing. Total $30

comment: Moa is a fun place to relax.  Busy after work.  Beers on tap are good.  Drink outside and watch people or inside.  Both are good.  They often have live music.Food is good.  I was impressed that my ceasar salad was cold, crisp, and even the croutons had crunch.Well done!

rest_name: Moa Tiki New Zealand Bar and Grill CCP
